items.title: Thousands of exposed GitHub repos, now private, can still be accessed through Copilot
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Security researchers warn that briefly exposed data on GitHub may persist in generative AI tools like Microsoft Copilot.
- Over 20,000 previously public GitHub repositories are still accessible via Copilot, affecting more than 16,000 organizations including Amazon, Google, IBM, and Microsoft.
- Lasso, a cybersecurity firm, discovered that Copilot could retrieve sensitive information even from repositories set to private or deleted, prompting recommendations for affected organizations to revoke compromised data.

items.title: ElevenLabs now lets authors create and publish audiobooks on its own platform
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- ElevenLabs now allows authors to publish AI-generated audiobooks on its own Reader app.
- The announcement follows a partnership with Spotify for AI-narrated audiobooks.
- The publishing program, previously in trial, is now open to all authors.
- Authors are paid approximately $1.10 for engagement of 11 minutes or more; average listening time is 19 minutes.
- Initially, payouts are available for U.S. authors and English titles, with plans for 32 supported languages in the future.
- ElevenLabs aims to compete with Audible, offering better royalty rates and creating a marketplace for authors.
- The initiative is part of ElevenLabs CEO Mati Staniszewski’s vision to enhance consumer experiences with AI technology in audiobooks.

items.title: German startup wins accolade for its fusion reactor design
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Proxima Fusion, a German nuclear fusion startup, published plans for a working fusion power plant in a peer-reviewed journal.
- Its ‘Stellaris’ design aims to operate reliably and continuously without the instabilities of other fusion reactors like tokamaks.
- The company has raised $35 million from the EU and German government, targeting a fully operational reactor by 2031.
- Competitors include Commonwealth Fusion Systems, backed by Bill Gates’s venture fund.
- The findings were published in ‘Fusion Engineering and Design’ to support open-source science.

items.title: Claude: Everything you need to know about Anthropic’s AI
items.summary:
- Anthropic's Claude models can perform various tasks like captioning, writing, and solving challenges.  
- Latest models include Claude 3.5 Haiku, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, and Claude 3 Opus; with Sonnet being the flagship model optimized for reasoning.  
- Pricing: Claude 3.5 Haiku ($0.80/million input tokens), Claude 3.7 Sonnet ($3/million input tokens), Claude 3 Opus ($15/million input tokens).  
- Available through Anthropic's API and platforms like Amazon Bedrock and Google Cloud.  
- Users can choose reasoning modes with Claude 3.7 Sonnet, enhancing its ability to analyze prompts.  
- Risks of AI models include potential inaccuracies, hallucinations, and copyright concerns from training data.

items.title: How much does ChatGPT cost? Everything you need to know about OpenAI’s pricing plans
items.summary:
- OpenAI’s ChatGPT offers a variety of pricing plans, including free and paid options for individuals, businesses, and educational institutions.
- The free version allows access to the GPT-4o mini model with limited features; users can save chat preferences and analyze uploaded data.
- ChatGPT Plus costs $20/month, allows 80 messages to GPT-4o every three hours, and includes more advanced features like multimodal capabilities.
- ChatGPT Pro, priced at $200/month, provides unlimited access to models and the latest features along with priority support.
- ChatGPT Team is available for $30/user/month, focusing on collaboration for small businesses, while ChatGPT Enterprise targets larger organizations with pricing based on user volume.
- OpenAI for Nonprofits offers discounted plans for eligible organizations, including ChatGPT Team and ChatGPT Enterprise at reduced rates.
- The article was updated on February 25, 2025, to reflect new pricing and features.

items.title: Y Combinator deletes posts after a startup’s demo goes viral
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- A demo from Optifye.ai, part of Y Combinator’s current cohort, led to criticism and YC removing the video from their social media.
- The demo showcased AI-powered software designed to monitor factory workers’ productivity in real-time, featuring a conversation between co-founders about a low-performing worker.
- The clip faced backlash on social media for promoting exploitative labor practices; however, some supported the approach, citing existing practices in certain industries.

items.title: Anthropic’s latest flagship AI might not have been incredibly costly to train
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Anthropic’s Claude 3.7 Sonnet cost "a few tens of millions of dollars" to train, requiring less than 10^26 FLOPs of computing power.
- The cost reflects how training state-of-the-art models is becoming relatively cheaper compared to previous models like GPT-4, which cost over $100 million.
- CEO Dario Amodei anticipates future models will be much larger and may cost billions, indicating rising costs for AI model development and deployment.

items.title: Perplexity launches $50M seed and pre-seed VC fund
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Perplexity is raising a $50 million seed and pre-seed investment fund.
- The majority of capital is from limited partners, with some from Perplexity's previous growth funds.
- Perplexity raised $500 million at a $9 billion valuation in December 2024.
- The fund is managed by Kelly Graziadei and Joanna Lee Shevelenko, co-founders of F7 Ventures.
- F7 Ventures has invested in startups, including women's health company Midi.
- It is unclear if Graziadei and Shevelenko will continue with F7 Ventures while managing the new fund.
- OpenAI also has an investment fund but claims it does not use its own capital for investments.

items.title: The people in Elon Musk’s DOGE universe
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has created a network of companies that supports engineers and tech talent, now intersecting with the U.S. federal government.
- TechCrunch identified individuals working with Musk related to the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) and their connections.
- The DOGE initiative aims at improving government efficiency and accountability, linked to President Trump’s commitment.
- Musk serves as an unpaid “Special Government Employee” and senior advisor to the president under DOGE, set to expire in July 2026.
- Current individuals involved include long-time confidants and new hires from Musk’s previous ventures like SpaceX and Twitter.

items.title: DOGE has an official ‘acting’ administrator, and it’s not Elon Musk, White House confirms
items.author: Amy Gleason
items.summary:
- Amy Gleason has been appointed as the acting administrator of DOGE, confirmed by the White House.
- This is the first acknowledgment of oversight for DOGE, previously leaving roles ambiguous regarding Elon Musk.
- DOGE was established through an executive order signed by President Trump, renaming the U.S. Digital Service.
- Gleason reports to the White House chief of staff, Susie Wiles.
- Musk remains deeply involved with DOGE despite not being its official head.

items.title: Anthropic’s Claude AI is playing Pokémon on Twitch — slowly
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Anthropic launched [Claude Plays Pokémon](https://www.twitch.tv/claudeplayspokemon) on Twitch, featuring Claude 3.7 Sonnet playing Pokémon Red.
- The AI model has successfully won three gym leader badges but still faces challenges, like getting stuck at a rock wall.
- The Twitch stream showcases Claude's thought process alongside gameplay, reminiscing about the earlier Twitch experiment, [Twitch Plays Pokémon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitch_Plays_Pok%C3%A9mon).

items.title: Lucid Motors CEO Peter Rawlinson steps down
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Lucid Motors announces Peter Rawlinson is stepping down as CEO and CTO, with Marc Winterhoff appointed as interim CEO.
- Rawlinson will serve as a strategic technical advisor to Turqi Alnowaiser, chairman of the board.
- The leadership change follows the launch of the Gravity SUV, as the company aims to recover from poor sales of its previous model, the Air sedan.
- Lucid Motors delivered 10,241 EVs in 2024, generating $808 million in revenue but still incurred a loss of $2.7 billion.

items.title: Apptronik’s humanoid robots take the first steps toward building themselves
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apptronik announces a new pilot partnership with Jabil to scale humanoid robot production.
- The deal follows a $350 million Series A funding round and an ongoing pilot with Mercedes-Benz.
- Jabil will manufacture the Apollo robot once it is commercially viable, with plans to have humanoids potentially build themselves.
- Apollo robots will perform simple tasks at Jabil’s factory to validate their capabilities, targeting 2026 for commercial production.

items.title: OpenAI rolls out deep research to paying ChatGPT users
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced on February 25, 2025, the rollout of its deep research feature to all paying ChatGPT users, including ChatGPT Plus, Team, Enterprise, and Edu subscribers.
- Each user will get 10 deep research queries per month; ChatGPT Pro users will receive 120 queries, up from 100 at launch.
- OpenAI is competing with Google and Perplexity in the deep research market, which aims to deliver value to AI subscription users. Google recently expanded its deep research agent to all Gemini Advanced users.

items.title: Framous is a new Mac app for adding device frames to screenshots
items.author: Charlie Chapman, Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Framous, a new Mac app, allows users to add device frames to screenshots for a more professional appearance.
- It is particularly useful for app developers, graphic designers, and journalists.
- Created by Dark Noise developer Charlie Chapman, Framous simplifies the process of adding frames, requiring just drag-and-drop or copy-paste actions.
- Features include automatic device frame detection, landscape mode for iPhones, and customization options like frame color and edge-to-edge mode.
- Future updates include more customization options, video support, and an iOS app planned for development.
- Available for free in the Mac App Store with a one-time fee of $19.99 to unlock all 2025 frames or a $9.99 yearly subscription.

items.title: Apple shareholders vote down anti-DEI proposal
items.summary:
- Apple shareholders rejected an anti-DEI proposal at the investor meeting on Tuesday.
- The proposal was made by the conservative group National Center for Public Policy Research (NPPR) and sought to end DEI activities.
- This proposal gained national attention amidst other tech companies trimming or eliminating DEI programs due to social and legal pressures.
- CEO Tim Cook indicated that changes might be necessary as the legal landscape evolves, according to reports.
keywords: National Center for Public Policy Research

items.title: Why OpenAI isn’t bringing deep research to its API just yet
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI is delaying the release of its deep research model to its developer API to assess AI persuasion risks.
- A recent whitepaper highlights concerns about AI's role in spreading misleading information at scale.
- The deep research model is currently deployed only in ChatGPT, not the API, due to the significant issues of misinformation and high computing costs.
- Tests showed that while the model is effective, it doesn't surpass human capabilities in persuasiveness.
- OpenAI is exploring ways to refine model performance before making it more widely available.

items.title: Tumblr backs Tapestry, a timeline app for the open social web
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Automattic-owned Tumblr financially backed [Tapestry](https://apps.apple.com/app/tapestry-by-iconfactory/id6448078074), a new app to organize feeds from various open web sources.
- Tapestry raised over $177,000 through Kickstarter in January 2024 and recently debuted in the App Store.
- Tumblr's funding will help develop a native macOS version of the app, which is currently available for iPad.
- Tapestry supports multiple sources like RSS, Mastodon, Bluesky, and more, allowing users to curate their own feeds and control information consumption.
- The app aims to enhance user customization and reduce reliance on tech giants’ algorithms.

items.title: Quora’s Poe now lets users create and share custom AI-powered apps
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Poe has launched a new feature called Poe Apps, allowing users to create custom AI-powered applications using various AI models.
- Users can specify models like OpenAI's o3-mini or Google’s Veo 2 in the App Creator tool.
- The App Creator translates user descriptions into code and custom logic in JavaScript.
- Example apps include transforming photos into 3D anime-style art and removing unwanted objects from images.
- Poe Apps can be shared online; support for iOS and Android is coming soon.
- Usage of AI models consumes a user's points balance; a free daily allotment is provided or users can subscribe for more.
- Quora indicates potential future monetization options for app creators.

items.title: Brex eyes $500M in revenue as it adds the likes of Anthropic and Robinhood as customers
items.summary:
- Brex expects annual net revenue to reach $500 million in 2025.
- The company reports 3x overall revenue growth year-over-year.
- Brex's enterprise business has grown by 80% year-over-year.
- The customer base includes over 150 public companies such as Anthropic, Arm, and Robinhood.
- CEO Pedro Franceschi anticipates cash-flow positivity in 2025 and a potential IPO afterwards.
- Brex has raised over $1.5 billion and was valued at over $12.3 billion at its peak in 2022.

items.title: Is this 32-year-old a brilliant founder, or a deceptive fraudster?
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- The criminal trial against fintech founder Charlie Javice began on February 21.
- JPMorgan Chase alleges she faked millions of customers to sell her company, Frank, for $175 million.
- Javice claims JPMorgan had 'buyer’s remorse' over regulatory changes affecting financial aid forms.

items.title: Opera integrates Bluesky, Slack, and Discord into its browser
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Opera announced the integration of Bluesky, Slack, and Discord into its browser sidebar.
- This addition aims to enhance user experience by reducing clutter from open tabs.
- The decision was made based on user feedback, and Bluesky is notable for being a newer social network with over 32 million users.
- Opera One, launched in 2023, includes features for organizing tabs and modular video/music players.

items.title: Sweden’s Lovable, an app-building AI platform, rakes in $15M after spectacular growth
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Lovable, a Swedish AI startup, raised $15 million in a pre-Series A round led by Creandum.
- It allows users to create apps easily without coding skills, claiming 500,000 users and over 25,000 new products daily.
- The platform reached $17 million in annual recurring revenue with 30,000 paying customers, showing rapid growth for a European startup.
- Founder Anton Osika emphasized Lovable's user-friendly approach compared to other AI coding platforms, combining technologies from OpenAI and Google.
- The company plans to integrate more third-party services and has drawn comparisons to the user satisfaction seen with Spotify.

items.title: What to expect from Amazon’s Alexa event on Wednesday
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Amazon is hosting an Alexa-focused event in NYC on Wednesday, the first major device presser in nearly two years.
- The event starts at 10 a.m. Eastern, hosted by Panos Panay, Amazon’s new devices chief.
- Amazon may introduce a new subscription for an upgraded Alexa, code-named Remarkable Alexa, priced between $5 and $10 a month.
- The upgraded Alexa aims for more natural interactions, allowing multiple requests in one command and autonomous actions.
- Amazon has struggled with Alexa's profitability, prompting a push for monetized subscriptions and services.
- Compatibility with existing devices and enhanced smart home capabilities are expected with the new Alexa.
- The launch has been delayed due to testing issues, possibly until the end of March.

items.title: DocUnlock wants to solve a customs bottleneck
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- DocUnlock aims to automate the tedious customs paperwork process for importers in the U.S.
- The platform integrates into customs brokers' email systems to streamline documentation, using AI to manage unstructured data.
- Founded in 2023, DocUnlock has a 100% retention rate and raised $3 million in pre-seed funding from various investors.

items.title: University spin-out Afynia secures $5M seed to commercialize its microRNA panel test for endometriosis
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Afynia Laboratories, a Canadian biotech startup from McMaster University, secured $5 million in seed funding for a blood test for endometriosis.
- Endometriosis affects nearly 200 million people globally, and diagnosis often takes years, delaying treatment.
- The test, named EndomiR, analyzes microRNA in blood to diagnose endometriosis more effectively than single biomarker tests.
- Afynia aims to simplify diagnosis, potentially reducing the average diagnosis time of upwards of seven years.
- They plan to launch the test in Canada this summer, with U.S. introduction expected next year.
- Funding was led by Bio-Rad Laboratories, with previous backing of $1.5 million in pre-seed funding from various investors.

items.title: Clicks brings its BlackBerry-style keyboard case to Android phones
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Clicks launches BlackBerry-style physical keyboard cases for Android devices.
- Available for Google Pixel, Motorola Razr+, and Samsung Galaxy S25, pre-orders start now.
- Pixel cases priced at $99; prices increase to $139 after March 21.
- Razr+ and Galaxy S25 cases also $99, with an increase to $139 post-deadline.
- Features include tactile feedback, backlit keys, USB-C charging, and a companion app for preferences.
- Cases tap into BlackBerry nostalgia; over 100,000 iPhone cases sold globally since 2024 launch.
- Some users have noted a learning curve for typing with the case, especially on iPhone.

items.title: YouTube is working to make ad slots less interruptive
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- YouTube announced changes to mid-roll ads effective May 12 to improve user experience and creator revenue.
- Fewer ads will be shown during interruptive moments; more ads will be placed at natural breaks in videos.
- Older videos will be updated to include ad slots at these natural breaks automatically.
- Creators can opt-out of automatic placements and keep some control over ad placements in YouTube Studio.
- YouTube is introducing a feature to help creators see if their ads are placed disruptively.
- A mix of auto and manual ads resulted in a 5% increase in revenue for some creators.
- The goal is to maintain viewer engagement by reducing interruptive ads.

items.title: FAA tests Starlink terminals as Musk claims Verizon tech is ‘not working’
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is testing SpaceX Starlink satellite internet terminals in the national airspace system.
- Elon Musk criticized Verizon’s $2 billion system, claiming it is "not working" and enhances risk for air travelers.
- The FAA is specifically evaluating the reliability issues in Alaska, testing Starlink terminals at facilities in Atlantic City and Alaska.
- Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy mentioned that Musk would help to "upgrade" the air traffic control system.
- There are concerns about possible conflicts of interest as Musk's employees have close access to federal agencies regulating his businesses.

items.title: Sam Bankman-Fried’s first post from prison isn’t even good
items.summary:
- Sam Bankman-Fried made his first public post on X while serving a 25-year prison sentence.
- His post responded to an ultimatum from Elon Musk to federal employees.
- SBF expressed sympathy for government workers, commenting on his own unemployment experience.
- FTX's token, FTT, surged 30% after his post.
- The method of how he posted from prison remains unclear, as inmates typically cannot access social media.

items.title: IBM’s $6.4B HashiCorp acquisition cleared by UK
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- The U.K.’s antitrust authority has approved IBM’s acquisition of HashiCorp worth $6.4 billion.
- The decision follows a 10-month period of scrutiny since IBM announced the acquisition in April 2024.
- The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) plans to publish its full rationale for the decision later.
- This acquisition aims to strengthen IBM’s position in the hybrid cloud space, following previous acquisitions of Red Hat and Apptio.
- The U.K. is attempting to project a pro-tech, pro-growth business stance amidst regulatory changes.
- The deal still awaits approval from the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC).

items.title: DeepSeek reopens access to its API after three-week pause
items.summary:
- Chinese AI startup DeepSeek has reopened access to its API after a three-week service halt due to capacity issues.
- Starting February 25, 2025, customers can now top up credits for using DeepSeek's API.
- DeepSeek's R1 reasoning model has gained attention for matching OpenAI models, prompting OpenAI to consider open-sourcing more technology.
- Concurrently, Alibaba announced a preview of its reasoning AI model, QwQ-Max, aiming for open-source deployment.

items.title: Microsoft cancels some of its AI data center leases
items.summary:
- Microsoft is reducing its data center footprint by canceling leases with multiple data center providers, totaling a couple hundred megawatts of capacity, equivalent to about two data centers.
- The reasons for this decision are unclear but suggest a potential reset of expectations for future AI demand.
- In contrast, the industry is expanding, with announcements of significant funding for data centers from figures like Donald Trump and companies like OpenAI and SoftBank.

items.title: Apple’s Developer service comes to China’s WeChat
items.summary:
- Apple announced the integration of its Developer service into China’s WeChat app on February 25, 2025.
- This service includes news and announcements for developers, traditionally offered via Apple's website and Developer app.
- The move targets declining iPhone sales in China, which fell by 11.1% in the last quarter due to local competition from brands like Oppo and Huawei.
- Apple is working on introducing AI technologies from Tencent and ByteDance to enhance its product offerings in China.

items.title: DoorDash to pay delivery workers nearly $17M for using tips to cover wages
items.summary:
- DoorDash agreed to pay $16.75 million to settle a lawsuit from New York’s attorney general.
- The lawsuit accused DoorDash of using customer tips to cover the base pay of workers from May 2017 to September 2019.
- Approximately 63,000 New York delivery workers will benefit from the settlement.
- DoorDash stated that the allegations were related to a pay model retired in 2019, emphasizing commitment to fair earnings.

items.title: Mitico raises $4.3M seed round to capture CO2 using ‘prehistoric chemistry’
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Mitico has raised a $4.3 million seed round to develop a cost-effective carbon capture technology using potassium carbonate pebbles.
- The company's approach can capture over 95% of CO2 in exhaust streams, offering a potential cost of less than $85 per metric ton captured.
- Mitico aims to market its technology to industrial boiler users initially, and later expand to major CO2 emitters like natural gas power plants.

items.title: Redalpine, Founders Fund back Magdrive’s electric thruster business
items.author: Aria Alamalhodaei
items.summary:
- Magdrive, a UK startup, has developed an electric propulsion system for satellites that boasts higher thrust and lower mass compared to traditional systems.
- The company secured $10.5 million in funding led by Swiss fund Redalpine, aiming to manufacture commercial products and expand operations.
- Magdrive's technology utilizes solid metal propellant to generate high-energy plasma, enabling new mission capabilities in the space industry.
- The startup's systems, Rogue and Warlock, offer scalability and the potential to use in-space materials as fuel, differentiating them from competitors.
- Scheduled demonstrations of the Rogue thrusters are planned for June 2023; future systems include Warlock in 2026 and Super Magdrive in 2027.

items.title: Quantum Machines raises $170M, says it’s working with more than half of all quantum computing companies
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Quantum Machines raised $170 million in a Series C funding round led by PSG Equity, with participation from Intel Capital and others.
- The company provides quantum control solutions and works with over half of the global quantum computing companies.
- Quantum Machines' technology helps reduce errors in quantum computing research, critical for building functional quantum computers.
- The startup experienced a significant uplift in valuation compared to previous fundraising rounds, originally pegged at $100 million.
- There are ongoing developments in the quantum computing sector, including innovations by Google and Microsoft, aiming for practical quantum applications in the next 5 to 10 years.

items.title: Adobe launches a Photoshop iPhone app
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Adobe introduces a mobile version of Photoshop for iPhone, available worldwide in the Apple App Store.
- The iPhone app includes both free and premium features with a subscription plan costing $7.99 monthly.
- Users can access core editing tools, such as layering, masking, and advanced AI tools like ‘Generative Fill’.

items.title: Serverless Cloud Platform Koyeb Integrates Tenstorrent’s AI Accelerators
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Koyeb now allows developers to utilize Tenstorrent’s AI accelerators shortly after the company raised nearly $700 million in funding.
- Tenstorrent’s AI processors are designed using the RISC-V architecture and offer an open-source neural network library, TT-NN, and programming model, TT-Metalium.
- Koyeb, founded by former Scaleway executives, provides a serverless cloud platform that automatically scales applications based on traffic demands.
- New instances include TT-N300S with 24GB GDDR6 memory and 466 FP8 TFLOPS, and TT-Loudbox with 96GB GDDR6 memory and 1,864 FP8 TFLOPS.
- Koyeb aims to be hardware-agnostic, positioning itself as an alternative to Nvidia's ecosystem.

items.title: Apple Watch shipments surge in India
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- In 2024, smartwatch shipments in India dropped 30% year-on-year, with Apple experiencing a 141% increase in shipments.
- This surge follows a decline of 57% for Apple in 2023.
- Counterpoint analysts predict the trend of consumers moving to advanced smartwatches will continue into 2025.
- Apple holds about 2% of India’s smartwatch market, which shipped 35 million units last year.
- The Apple Watch led the premium smartwatch segment, comprising 50% of total sales priced above $230.

items.title: Perfect taps $23M to fix the flaws in recruitment with AI
items.summary:
- Startup Perfect, based in Israel, has raised $23 million in seed funding to improve recruitment processes using AI.
- The platform helps recruiters by saving them up to 25 hours of work per week and has grown its customer base from 20 to 200 businesses, including Fiverr and eToro.
- Perfect's founder, Eylon Etshtein, aims to replace outdated recruitment methods with proprietary data and automation to enhance recruitment efficiency.

items.title: Google launches a free AI coding assistant with very high usage caps
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google introduced a free version of its AI coding assistant, **Gemini Code Assist for Individuals**, which allows natural language interaction for code editing.
- The tool offers **180,000 code completions** per month and **240 chat requests** daily, far exceeding the free GitHub Copilot's limits.
- It uses a **Gemini 2.0 AI model** with a **128,000-token context window** for handling complex codebases.
- The public preview for developers starts on the launch date (Tuesday).
- The service aims to attract new developers and potentially convert some to paid enterprise plans in the future.

items.title: EU’s top court ruling on Android Auto antitrust referral could put interoperability requests in the fast lane
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- The Court of Justice of the EU affirmed that refusal of interoperability by a dominant market player can constitute antitrust abuse.
- The ruling stems from Google’s past refusal to allow Enel X Italia's app access to Android Auto, deemed an abuse by Italy's competition authority.
- The court established criteria for justifying interoperability refusals, including technical impossibilities and potential security risks.
- Google expressed disappointment with the ruling, emphasizing its focus on user-centric development and the limited demand for the Enel-requested feature in Italy.

items.title: US employee screening giant DISA says hackers accessed data of more than 3M people
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- DISA Global Solutions suffered a data breach affecting over 3.3 million individuals.
- The breach was reported in a filing to Maine's attorney general on February 25, 2025.
- The cyber incident was discovered on April 22, 2024, with a hacker accessing the network on February 9, 2024.
- Stolen data includes Social Security numbers, financial account information, and government-issued IDs.
- Over 360,000 Massachusetts residents were confirmed affected by the breach. 
- DISA indicated it lacked sufficient logs to determine the specifics of the data accessed by the hacker.

items.title: Thoma Bravo raises €1.8B for its first European fund
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Private equity firm Thoma Bravo closed its inaugural European fund at €1.8 billion ($1.9 billion).
- The fund aims to invest in mid-sized software companies across Europe.
- Thoma Bravo has previously invested around €14 billion in Europe since 2011.
- The closing of the fund reflects an opportunity to expand in a region where North American VC firms are retreating.
- The firm has launched its London office in 2023, marking its first hub outside the U.S.

items.title: Fyre Festival 2 is coming, and it already sounds bananas (and not in a good way)
items.summary:
- Billy McFarland announces Fyre Festival 2 scheduled for May 30 to June 2, 2025, in Isla Mujeres, Mexico.
- Ticket prices range from $1,400 to an excessive $1.1 million, despite no confirmed artists.
- McFarland’s legal status regarding international travel is unclear as he faces past convictions from the original Fyre Festival debacle in 2017.

items.title: Automattic-owned Beeper is releasing redesigned desktop and iOS apps
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Automattic, owner of WordPress.com, acquired Beeper for $125 million in 2024.
- Beeper is launching redesigned beta apps for iOS and desktop based on its merger with Texts.com.
- The new apps are faster, consume less battery, and will eventually migrate users from the old app. 
- Data will be stored on-device in upcoming versions, featuring on-device encryption and multi-account support.
- Future Mac app updates will include iMessage support.
- Beeper was founded by Eric Migicovsky, who is now focused on reviving Pebble smartwatches.

items.title: 1,000 artists release ‘silent’ album to protest UK copyright sell-out to AI
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- A group of 1,000 musicians released a "silent album" titled "Is This What We Want?" to protest U.K. copyright law changes.
- The album features recordings of empty studios and spaces, symbolizing the impact of proposed legislation allowing AI use of artists' content without payment.
- The album's track titles convey a message against potential music theft to benefit AI companies.
- Ed Newton-Rex, the project organizer, leads a campaign against AI training without licensing, with a petition signed by over 47,000 creatives.
- The album will be available on music platforms with proceeds going to charity Help Musicians, highlighting growing global concerns among artists.

items.title: UK’s internet watchdog toughens approach to deepfake porn
items.summary:
- Ofcom, U.K.'s internet safety regulator, issues new draft guidance to combat online threats against women and girls under the Online Safety Act.
- The guidance aims to tackle intimate image abuse, including deepfake porn, which is a priority for enforcement.
- Child safety campaigners express frustration over delays in implementing the Online Safety Act, which became law in September 2023.
- Initial enforcement of core OSA duties is set for next month, with full compliance guidance becoming enforceable by 2027.
- Ofcom emphasizes a 'safety by design' approach for online platforms to improve user safety and reduce risks associated with their services.
- The latest recommendations include using hash matching technology for detecting and removing abusive intimate imagery, especially deepfakes, amidst rising incidents reported in 2023.
